title: 112_s3196
content: The Act titled "National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force Act of 2012" establishes the National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force under the Small Business Administration. The Task Force focuses on small business concerns owned and controlled by women. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force is established to provide advice and policy recommendations to the Administrator, Assistant Administrator, Congress, the President, and other federal departments. It consists of 15 members, including small business owners controlled by women and individuals with expertise in women's business and entrepreneurship research. The National Women's High-Growth Business Bipartisan Task Force consists of 15 members, including small business owners controlled by women and individuals representing women's business organizations. Members are appointed by various Senate and House committees. The Task Force under the Committee on Small Business of the House of Representatives consists of members appointed by the Administrator, with initial appointments to be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Geographic diversity, including representation from rural areas, and a limit of 8 members from the same political party are considerations for appointments. The Task Force members elect a Chairperson and serve for 3 years, with initial appointees serving for 4 years. Vacancies in the Chairperson position are filled promptly. The Task Force members are appointed for 5-year terms, with vacancies filled within 30 days. Appointees cannot be federal employees. The Task Force members serve without compensation and are reimbursed for travel expenses. They review plans affecting small businesses in the public and private sectors. The Task Force members review and advise on plans to improve access to capital, credit, and markets for women-owned small businesses. They also monitor and promote federal programs for the formation and development of such businesses, develop initiatives to encourage startups, and advise on an annual comprehensive plan for joint efforts between public and private sectors. The Task Force, comprised of members who review and advise on plans to enhance access to capital, credit, and markets for women-owned small businesses, may hold hearings, establish task groups, and request information from federal agencies to fulfill its duties related to women-owned businesses and intellectual property rights. The Task Force may use the United States mails, accept gifts, and hold meetings not less than 3 times a year, as well as at the call of the Chairperson or upon request from specific members or committees. Federal agencies are encouraged to participate in Task Force activities. The Task Force encourages participation from representatives of Federal agencies in meetings, where they can provide resources but not vote. Meetings are typically held at the Administration's headquarters unless agreed otherwise. The Administrator provides necessary support for each meeting. The Task Force is required to submit reports within 30 days after each fiscal year. At the end of each fiscal year, the Task Force must submit a report to the President and relevant committees detailing its activities, findings, recommendations, and legislative/administrative actions to promote intellectual property rights for high-growth small businesses owned by women. The Task Force must submit a report at the end of each fiscal year detailing its activities, findings, recommendations, and legislative/administrative actions to promote small business concerns owned and controlled by women. The report should include any concurring or dissenting views of the Administrator and the minutes of each Task Force meeting. Additionally, the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration, in consultation with the Task Force, must conduct studies twice a year on issues important to small businesses owned and controlled by women. The Task Force, in consultation with the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration, conducts studies twice a year on issues critical to advancing small business concerns owned and controlled by women. Topics include federal contracts, access to credit, investment capital for women entrepreneurs, and intellectual property rights enforcement. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy may contract with a public or private entity to conduct studies on issues related to small businesses owned by women. The results of these studies are submitted in a report to the Task Force and relevant Senate and House committees. The Task Force must make reports available to the public online. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Task Force. SEC. 4. REPEAL. Final Reports must be submitted by the Interagency Committee on Women's Business Enterprise and the National Women's Business Council within 90 days of this Act's enactment. The reports should contain specific information as outlined in the Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988. The Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 is amended by repealing title IV. The Small Business Act is also amended to remove references to the Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 and update terminology to refer to small business concerns owned and controlled by women. The Women's Business Ownership Act of 1988 is amended by removing title IV. The Small Business Act is updated to refer to small business concerns owned and controlled by women. Subsections (b) and (c) amendments will take effect 90 days after enactment. Subclauses (VIII), (IX), and (X) are struck.
